Posted: February 3
Early Access Review
								Fun and challenging, without being punishing. A lighthearted glee is evident in every aspect of this turn based, hex-map strategy and collection game. Music is some of the best, and the Narrator is great. Unfortunately there seems to be very little of said Narrator. With his the only voice of the game, other than gibberish played over text, Pit People can rely too heavily on its otherwise excellent sound design. I found that with no actual dialogue to draw me in I just skipped past more and more of the admittedly  clever and funny story as soon as I read it. Plays well with a good strategic options base. Tons of mostly cosmetic items to collect. Wide and shallow with equipped items dictating character class for humans while creatures you recruit can only use their default skills. Since you can't predict the type of fight you'll face this specialization limits their utility and use.Too much fun with co-op, can't wait for more.

Posted: February 27
Early Access Review
This Game Rocks!I have never been a fan of any sort of turn based games, but this one is a true gem. My skepticism was snuffed out by the humor and large amount of working content already available. The turn based combat can be rather amusing and I've even been on the edge of my seat in some of the battles, too. The co-op is incredibly fun with good friends. Hours have been lost trying to build the right tag team combo with, of course, the coolest looking apparel for my troops. I understand if you're not a fan of turn based games, but give this one a shot. It's way better with friends and the mindless exploring isn't too bad. My one and only con for this game is the story block. At the moment, the story is a work in progress and seems to be releasing in increments. That's not entirely bad, but I'd really love to dig into it all at once and see where Horatio ends up.Other than that, this game is great and would recommend to anyone!

Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								Battleblock theatre was more or less my entry in this wacky world The Giant Chicken threw me into, and I had a nice time. It was irritating at times, but they proved they can make a good and instantly challenging platformer, while at the same time, throwing exellent humor at you from all sides.Then I played Castle Crashers, where the same chicken proved it could make an excellent beat-em-up but this time, they had more subtile humor. Now, you got this. Pit People. The Chicken's shot at fire emblem. And it is utterly glorious. Right away they give you rules of engagement that, classically, you'll forget instantly, and wonder why you keep losing. Such as how you should only be using maces against dudes with helmets. I forgot about that and wondered why I wasn't doing much damage.The narrator jumped out of Battleblock and right into Pit People, and he makes me truly happy. Ulitimately, a chicken programmed this game.A chicken lent it massiveness to this game, and speaks in the royal 'we'.If that does not give you reason as to why you should play this gem; I nary know what will.Its in early access and I don't care. I have much history with them, and this is about as solid as all the others.Happy to support the chicken once again.I'd keep making chicken jokes, but at some point they'd get rather fowl.easy 9/10

Posted: February 22
Early Access Review
								Pit People is a fun isometric turn-based combat-strategy game made by the lovely folks who created Battleblock Theatre and Castle Crashers. Pit People features many recruitable characters, including (but not limited to) Pixies, Spiderpeople, Unicorns, Cannibals, Zombies, Gnomes, Cupcakes, Mushrooms, Robots, and a pesky moustachioed man named Horatio.In Pit People, William Andrew Stamper is the incredibly charismatic and not-at-all-psychotic Narrator, just as he was in Battleblock Theatre. Now, onto the gameplay itself. While it is early access, the combat is still quite sound, and I've yet to encounter any bugs. One of the only issues that I've encountered is the fact that the main storyline is incredibly short (which is understandable, given the fact that the game is still in Early Access). Despite this, there are still dozens of side-quests to occupy your time, as well as multi-player combat in The Pit.Just like Battleblock Theatre and Castles Crashers, you can play the majority of the game with another player, in Co-Op Mode. Unlike BT and CC, you can only play multiplayer Co-Op with ONE other player (which is understandable, it would be rather difficult to balance a four-player Co-Op combat system, unless every player was restricted to 3 fighters instead of the usual 6.) I highly recommend this game for people who enjoy turn-based combat and comedy similar to Battleblock Theatre and Castle Crashers.

Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								Still in early access, but quite a fair price as these things go, especially from a dev with a good rep.The game may or may not be close to the finished article, I don't know, but there are a few obvious gaps in gamplay styles. I'm not sure what their plans are, but i hope they don't mess it up by trying to be too clever or add nonsense.Basically, leave the city, capture monsters/heroes, use them in battle. There are no paid perks and after a short time of yomping around the map I'd picked up a few characters to play with. I'm not sure the balancing is quite right, and the leaderboard is very basic and does nothing to encourage participation.But the real strength of Pit People is in the actual battle gameplay, which is very straightforward and easy to get to grips with. I'm not sure if the game is designed for tablets too, but it has that vibe. You command your troop movements, but they decide what to do when they get there. Sometimes that's a joy, other times a pain.I liked the game, and I have definately had a great time with it and got my money's worth. But I will wait now for the launch version and take it up again then.In the meantime I'd have no hesitation in recommending this game to anyone who likes turn based strategy. It isn't Advance Wars, but it's still pretty good.

Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								A friend and I recently purchased the game for eachover as we are both big Behometh fans. We were not dissapointed. After playing it for almost 6 hours straight these are my impressions:The level of customisable aspects for characters seems equally as vast as in previous titles.There is also a plethora of completely different characters, with even the weirder characters seeming to fit well into the world that they have made (e.g the cupcake that heals others by flinging little bits of themselves at allies)The main story that is currently in the games has very funny and well made cutscences and dialogue if a little short (But that is to be expected with an early access game and is more than made up for with things like the Pit or Insane Difficulty Mode)Their appears to be a wide number of sidequests and random things to do.My only complaint is the weight system for equipping weapons and armor makes choosing some of the cooler weapons annoying as it involves having to reshuffle the rest of the equipment.Definitely worth the purchase and I look forward to further content being added!

Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								My playtime in this so far has felt like I experienced a twisted hybrid of Fire Emblem meets Adventure Time, and I'm having a blast with the hours I've put into it at the time of writing this.Pit People sports a pretty wacky lineup of playable characters, music and art style which I feel have really tied in well in its current released state, of course if you aren't a fan of that certain style or Turn-Based Combat than this one might completely go over your head with little notice.As of writing this the game comes with a reasonable roster of characters, bunch of unlocks - purely cosmetic and some that add different elements, solo/co-cop/pvp, a fairly large world to explore which I think cycles through a few variations, heaps of side quests and a main story line which isn't complete yet as of right now, I think i spent about half an hour/an hour to complete whats available of it, the story line that is.All-in-all if you're a fan of Turn-Based Combat I think you should definitely give this one a try, even if you aren't and have the time, fire up a video on the interwebs and have a see if this might tickle your fancy. I feel like it's a pretty solid title, especially for an Early Access, probably the best $15 I spent in quite some time. Oh and the narration is awesome too, if only I had it for my daily life routine.

Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
 Wonderful Game It has a lot of character and it looks as though a great deal of thought was put into every aspect of it. Even the beastiary leaves you with a smirk after seing the illustrations.I will say though that the game feels built more for controllers. M+kb navigation of menues can be irritating at times. Given its current state I still can boast that it is more than worth the 15 USD price tag and honestly in hindsight I would have paid twice that. It already has over 1000 items and 100 quests leaving so much to be discovered beneath the surface. The one main drawback is the fact is only has a few story missions  currently .  Items Currently items of the same type act uniformly aside from elemental damage and resistance. There are a couple items that have interesting effects like slow and knockback but generally you are choosing between lightwight with high damage/movement/dodge or heavy that are more survivable. The non human characters have less customization but I have yet to see an item that I felt was not thoughtfully made and memorable.  Quests The quests are absolutely bonkers. There are some delivery missions and find this missions but even something you would intitially dismiss in other games turns out to be comedic. For instance  in one side quest you find a lizard and are tasked with taking it to its owner. The owner immediatly says he is going to eat it when you find him. You find out the lizard is sentient and blows up his owner telepathically.   Characters  All of the characters names are procedurally generated with a huge pool to choose from. There are a decent amount of types of enemies and even the worst of them is still viable with the right team. There is some balanceing that needs to be done still. One of the ways they balance currently is by making larger units take up more space on your roster. For example you have 6 slots after unlocking the final ones with in game currency. These can be filled in the following ways.Huge Unit = 3 slotsLarge Unit = 2 slotsRegular Unit = 1 slotsPair of Small Units = 1 slotSome units can spawn up to 6 spawn units during each fight.In this way a 2v2 arena fight could theoretically have 8 entities on the field or 84.  8 massive troll moms without thier spawn/ 12 gorgons and up to 72 spawn  Difficulty  Overall the game is not incredibly difficult after learning the basics but with the inclusion of Insane mode and elite enemies you will be pulling your hair out. Conclusion  Remembering that this is an early access game and everything is subject to change, I give it a perfect 5/7 stars.  Look forward to seeing you in the PIT.

Early Access Review
								Pit People is the newest nugget of raw charm from our friends at The Behemoth. It plays like a sort of manager-slash-isometric strategy game, with various units dressed in silly attire. The game doesn't by any means feel "Complete" but it's still in early access, so the amount of story that's out can be forgiven. Given Pit People's current price I will cautiously reccomend it, you'll love this game if you come to Behemoth for the charm and cartoony gore, however if you're looking for a strategy game, maybe look at a video first, instead of my poorly-written review.

Early Access Review
								My playtime in this so far has felt like I experienced a twisted hybrid of Fire Emblem meets Adventure Time, and I'm having a blast with the hours I've put into it at the time of writing this.Pit People sports a pretty wacky lineup of playable characters, music and art style which I feel have really tied in well in its current released state, of course if you aren't a fan of that certain style or Turn-Based Combat than this one might completely go over your head with little notice.As of writing this the game comes with a reasonable roster of characters, bunch of unlocks - purely cosmetic and some that add different elements, solo/co-cop/pvp, a fairly large world to explore which I think cycles through a few variations, heaps of side quests and a main story line which isn't complete yet as of right now, I think i spent about half an hour/an hour to complete whats available of it, the story line that is.All-in-all if you're a fan of Turn-Based Combat I think you should definitely give this one a try, even if you aren't and have the time, fire up a video on the interwebs and have a see if this might tickle your fancy. I feel like it's a pretty solid title, especially for an Early Access, probably the best $15 I spent in quite some time. Oh and the narration is awesome too, if only I had it for my daily life routine.

Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								Written review below, I also made a video here:  Pit People Co-Op ReviewHIghly recommend ths game! Got into the PC Beta and was happy to see that all the progress we had there was moved onwards to the early access. As The Behemoth mentioned, the early access period is only because they realized the game was in a fun playable state. It feels extremely polished from a gameplay standpoint and only really a few gripes I could notice. In co-op, if playing with controller, the only to even begin playing is to hit the F2 button which is a little unintuitive, especially if you're away from the keyboard. Further, the camera is shared between players so it's a little hard to navigate through a large map if you end up on both sides. Outside of this though, the game is hilariously funny and well made. Really awesome and well made so far with plenty of co-op quests to really have fun with. Nice to have local co-op, haven't tried single player yet but I'm betting it will be super fun as well.

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								So, this is one of the first reviews I've written, so if you disagree with what I say that's fine!To start off with I will just list some of the basic pros and cons-ProsBy The BehemothNo microtransactionsf2p, f2w.A vast variety of customizations, from characters to weapons to... to... HATS!!!Easy to learn, easy to master (but hard to battle other people who have mastered the game 20/10)Very addictive and fun.~ConsPaid (although this isn't very much an issue, most games are paid and it is quite cheap compared to other games which are lesser of Pit People... im talking to you, Overwatch)There is a bit of grinding (not too much though)It is in early access still, so there will be some unwelcome glitches and, unfortunately, exploits (although i have not heard of any exploits)It is addictive (yes this can be a bad thing)Now to describe what the game is like!The game itself is very simple, a team crafting, (slightly) strategized turn-based 2d game. The graphics are top-notch (3D isn't necessary for every game that exists). You can have at maximum 6 fighters in your team, although you may find that you have to have less, as some characters take up more than 1 slot due to sheer awesomeness. There is a wide variety of different species that you can collect, and lots of items to customize them with. If there is something you dont want, ring up a friend in the oversized phonebox to the far left of the city, and you can easily swap items instantly. You can hold up to 500 recruits in this game. Also, some of the species would be the demi-clops, rainbow unicorn and pixie.Now to the actual game mechanics!As you are in a battle, you take it in turns to move your team to your desired positons. But, beware, all species have weaknesses. While crafting your team, you can see their health, move points, defense, dodge chance, heal, special abilities and defenses (like freeze resistance). All characters have up to 5 move points. Characters can become the hero to have stat boosts, like health, damage, and usually move points. Now, back to fighting itself! In a battle, each tile is a hexagon. Each hexagon you move costs 1 move point. Some hexagons are different, and damage your team or cost 2 move points, or just can't be moved onto. Some flying creatures, like the pixie, can fly over gaps and water no problem (water is what costs 2 move points). You can have 2 main types of attackers - melee and ranged. But, if you choose so, you can have a troop with melee and range! But the range will not be very powerful, or, if you are a mortar or ranger, the melee will not be very powerful. If your troops can target multiple enemies, they decide which they will attack. This means you really need to make sure you move your character to the exact spot you want them to be, so that you attack the enemy you need to be dead.If you are lazy, or not exactly the best at the game, or have a team that is too big to control (some characters come with 2 people in only 1 space, so the max amount of characters you can have is 12) you can turn on the Auto Battler! This will move your characters instantly, although it may not always be very reliable. Only use it if you know that it will work well with your team.That's all for now...     -ProNub

Posted: January 18
Early Access Review
								Ah yes, Pit People, my new favorite! Even on its unfinished state.THE GAMEThe game is a turn-based RPG strategy with the witty humor and a beautiful cartoonish art style that made me fell in love with The Behemoth's games. Its a simple, yet clear take to Turn-Based Strategies, a genre that I was completely unfamilliar of. You can explore the world to kidnap recruit other fighters not only because of their stats, but their names too, find more gold MONEYYYYYY and loot, and undertake a LOT of other sidequests other than story mode.(more on that later) The game also has a multikill indicator and its the most satisfying thing ive ever heard.THE STORYAlthough short, it was hilarious! And honestly the very antagonistic narrator (who's VA also voiced the narrator from BBT) that is also a giant space bear is slowly becoming my new favorite bad guy and might even kick Bill Cipher from the TV show Gravity Falls (which is kinda hard tbh) from the "Best Villan" pedastal of my heart. The first snippet of the story already features fourth wall-beraking antics, and a really meta narrator that proclamed himself God of this post-apocalyptic hex-patterned earth. Plus the fully animated cutscenes are really cool!MUSICThe. Soundtrack. Is. Gud. Pls. Listen. 11/10THINGS I WAS slightly BOTHERED ATSuggestions>It was kinda hard to know what fighter you are currently selecting right now even with my 23-inch monitor on my PC well then, its been updated to a yellow outline for the selected fighter! It's now eaiser to see what fighter are you currently selecting right now.>the lack of a mac version aaaaaaaa (im aware that a mac verison would come soon tho)>more compatibility with touch screened laptops, so I was able to try the game in a laptop with a touch screen although with a option to include a end turn button on screen (and shaking btw) was a bit helpful, I personally think that it needs a bit more essential controls like cancel placement and player switch for tablet PCs (Surface Pro, Wacom Mobile Studio Pro, and the likes) and 2-n-1 convertables (Lenovo Yoga)

Posted: March 29
Early Access Review
								OMG where do I start?  Okay first of all if you are a fan of turn based strategy and must play all of them stop reading this and buy the game now.  If you are new to the genre but are interested in tactical games I can truly recommend this for you.  If you are seasoned turn based strategy fan this is also for you.  For starters I want to say that the combat is very well streamlined.  In most TBS games you move your character, choose a direction and then choose a type of attack.  If you are a healer you choose your character,  move him into position, choose your spell and finally heal who you want to heal.  In Pit Poeple this ihs simplified.  The healer character will simply heal whoever it can within it's range while dealing damage to itself.  This may seem oversimplified but it tends to work and speed up the healing process. Combat is also streamlined and faced paced.  You simple move your character into postion and he will choose to attack whomever he wants.  It sounds dumb but it works well in the game.  There area good amount of weapons, armor and charactrer classes to keep you guys.In terms of audio the music is just simply fantastic,  You can tell they had alot of fun coming up with great lively muslc that will tickle your funny bone.  Sounds effects and the narration is through the roof.  I did find some of the jokes totally lame but In the spirit of the game it was perfect.To sum it up,  I'm an avid TBS gamer and this was a complete and total surprise!+Excellent animation and graphics+Psuedo open world gameplay+Excellent memorable soundtrack and voice acting+Simplified TBS controls that are streamlined and keeps it fast paced-Main quest super short-still in early accessOnce this game is complete I can recommend it to anyone who has ever liked a TBS tacitcal game. Kudos to behemoth

Posted: January 28
Early Access Review
								I'll start this off with saying that I'm normally not into games like Pit People; It's not generally a type of game I look to play. However, Pit People is definitely an exeption! So after "beating" the early access version, here are my Pro's and Con's:Pros:+ Great, colorful artstyle.+ Exceptional writing and voice acting.+ Very funny dialog and cutscenes.+ Fast-paced gameplay.+ Working online arena mode.+ Expansive world map.+ Large amount of character upgrades (armor, weapons, etc).Cons: - The game is in early access, so as of now it's lacking in terms of content.- While the game stays interesting the entire way though, if you're not open-minded or a fan of this genre, I don't think you'll enjoy it.Notes:* Lack of explaination / tutorial in worldmap and town area. I'm assuming this is due to early access.* After finishing the early access story, it seems the only things to do are grind for gear and play arena. ---While Pit People is in early access, I could definitely see myself paying full price for it if I had found it post full release. It's a cute, well-written, adventure that makes me very impatient for the full release.If you're unsure about buying this, I would very much say to do so if you're okay with an incomplete story as of now. If you're not okay with that, I'd say to wait untill full release and pick it up then.When this game is fully released, I'll make sure to write an updated review on my Medium[medium.com] or  Blog.[kyotoshift.com]

Another complaint I have is that once you leave the secret area, you can't go back which is frustrating because I accidentally left it without getting my prize (I know it was my fault, but I was confused and I didn't know what was happening). Here are the bugs I've encountered so far(I know there's a bug report option, but I think I have to be logged in to their site to report it. Either that or I'm really dumb lol): Invisible objects and entitys in the overworld and in battle, killing or an enemy killing an ivisible entity crashes the game, game crashes whenever I complete the first Moltenasia quest. But this is still early access so obviously they're going to fix these bugs. Other than the bugs the game is great! (There's also lots of stale/dead memes in the game. This isn't really a complaint I'd just thought let people know lol)EDIT: I've found out that you can redo the secret area switches so that's nice!EDIT 2: The newest update fixed the invisible bug!

Early Access Review
								Written review below, I also made a video here:  Pit People Co-Op ReviewHIghly recommend ths game! Got into the PC Beta and was happy to see that all the progress we had there was moved onwards to the early access. As The Behemoth mentioned, the early access period is only because they realized the game was in a fun playable state. It feels extremely polished from a gameplay standpoint and only really a few gripes I could notice. In co-op, if playing with controller, the only to even begin playing is to hit the F2 button which is a little unintuitive, especially if you're away from the keyboard. Further, the camera is shared between players so it's a little hard to navigate through a large map if you end up on both sides. Outside of this though, the game is hilariously funny and well made. Really awesome and well made so far with plenty of co-op quests to really have fun with. Nice to have local co-op, haven't tried single player yet but I'm betting it will be super fun as well.

Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								I'm not one for many turn-based combat games. Xcom and Civ are my only exceptions honestly, and I'm not very good at either of them. I do enjoy them nonethless. Pit People was hanging on the edge for me; I love Behemoth and their games and humour, but the whole turn-taking thing was a bit of a step away from their usual slash-fest style. However, I had some money and time to spare so I thought I'd give their new game a real chance, and man, am I thankful I did. Pit People is a wonder (even in early access) to play. The usual from Behemoth can be expected: a crazy and cartoonish art style, over-the-top humour and stupidity, but the new direction this game takes is suprisingly well done and very simple yet fun to play. It doesn't require a whole lot of planning and thought like other turn-based games do. Simply move your characters to where you want them to go and they will attack who they think is the best, provided that they can. You can't target specific enemies, which I thought was awful at first, until I realised that all-in-all, it works very well. Depending on your weapon depends on how you attack. For example, melee weapons such as swords will be just one tile away for an attack to occur, but if a character say throws axes, you need to position them two tiles away instead so they can throw the axes towards an enemy. If they can target multiple enemies at once, they may split the damage if the AI deems it necessary to, or just attack one enemy for more damage. I like this simple formula that avoids the player themselves setting up positioning as well as attacks, and it's very easy once you get the hang of it. The combat isn't the most in-depth ever seen in a turn-based game, but in my opinion, it succeeds because of this. It creates a fast-paced action game where good positioning will win you the game, sort of like chess in a way. The other section is a pokemon styled run-around a map and find things game. You can seek out enemies that then take you into a more focused battle, and the best part is the quests, which allow for a lot of freedom to do what you want to do instead of sectioned levels. The story is crazy just like all of Behemoth's games, and I won't spoil it (even though there is only a certain amount of these story quests available currently) but there's a giant teddy bear that has crashed into the Earth. The narrator as always is ridiculous and funny. Customisation is plentiful and once again, outrageous. The hub town holds a market place for new fighters and weapons, an arena named the pit sort of like a colosseum as well as a home for you to mess with your characters and team. Overall, awesome game and a real treat to play. Simple, elegant, funny and over-the-top turn-based action with what seems to be a mind-boggling but intriguing story that never lets up on quick remarks, twists and plot. Support this game and Behemoth! They deserve it :D

Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								As a foreword this review was posted on the 6/2/17 and is with regards to the early access version of the game.Pit people is a delightful little strategy game by The Behemoth with narration by Will Stamper. In other words if you enjoyed the zany comedy of Battleblock Theatre, Castle Crashers or Alien Hominid then you will probably enjoy the style of humour found here. Whether it is the main 'story', multipart quests or the shorter sidequests the dialogue is constistently funny without getting too repetitive.The gameplay is a simplistic turn based combat system that takes place over a hexagonal grid. You assemble a team via collecting new units by defeating enemy armies and then customising them with various collectible items, mostly cosmetics but with some offering varied stats or attack styles. While the player's control over their units is limited (you pick where they move but not who they attack) your ability to customise the contents of your team adds a lot of depth to what you can do. Fans of games such as X-Com or Fire Emblem will likely enjoy what the game has to offer but it is also accessible enough for players new to the genre.Multiplayer operates smoothly with no real connection problems and offers both local and online co-op and versus. While some units may currently be considered suboptimal and others might be considered above average there is no feeling of there being a single perfect team composition in multiplayer, versus matches often featuring relatively varied teams.At present the main concern to be had with the game is that it is incomplete. Considering the low price I'd say even in it's unfinished state you will likely get your monies worth, especially as it seems bug free (in my experience at least) but if you are only planning to play the single player content you might want to wait for the full release. At present the storyline  consists of the tutorial content and a single mission, with numerous subquests and 4 quest chains also available. Hopefully the full release will expand upon this considerably, ideally with additional unit types being added as well.

								Pit People doesn't just look "promising" in it's current state, it's already simply an amazing game.It's a game that can be as simple or as in-depth as you want it to be and there's already tons of content to enjoy, all in The Behemoths signature style (little disclaimer here, the story is far from finished right now but there is A LOT to do already, ultimately, deciding on wether or not to get the game at the moment comes down to how you want to play it).The developers are engaged and responsive to community feedback in a way I haven't seen before, definitely Early Access done right.You can wait for the official game launch or get it in Early Access right now, either way you'll be getting more than your money's worth.

Posted: March 4
Early Access Review
								Did you ever feel, like your life was incomplete? Did you regret, not being able to shoot your enemies with a bow made from roses, while wearing a bow tie and a top hat?In this case, Pit People might be your saviour. This colourful and humorous turn-based strategy-game is not only easily accessible for rookies, but offers an enjoyable experience for everyone with a taste for absurd humour. While it does offer you a Co-op-mode, it is equally as fun to play just by yourself. Quests and fights do not take a lot of time, allowing for a player to drop in or out, even if he has merely a few minutes time. That said, the customization-feature would let you spend hours, equipping your recruits with ridiculous outfits and weapons, if you so desire. Quests and storylines are filled with pop-cultural references and the soundtrack is certainly unique.A minor point of criticism is the lack of information concerning status/wapon effects. For example, you can tell by purple bubbles surrounding them, that a character has been poisoned. However, it does not tell you, how long they are afflicted by it and how much damage they will suffer from it, in an easy way. This kind of information should be presented to the player in an unmistakable way. The game itself is nonetheless absolutely worthy of your attention and I can give a hearty recommendation to buy it, without the shadow of a doubt.

Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								I'm not one for many turn-based combat games. Xcom and Civ are my only exceptions honestly, and I'm not very good at either of them. I do enjoy them nonethless. Pit People was hanging on the edge for me; I love Behemoth and their games and humour, but the whole turn-taking thing was a bit of a step away from their usual slash-fest style. However, I had some money and time to spare so I thought I'd give their new game a real chance, and man, am I thankful I did. Pit People is a wonder (even in early access) to play. The usual from Behemoth can be expected: a crazy and cartoonish art style, over-the-top humour and stupidity, but the new direction this game takes is suprisingly well done and very simple yet fun to play. It doesn't require a whole lot of planning and thought like other turn-based games do. Simply move your characters to where you want them to go and they will attack who they think is the best, provided that they can. You can't target specific enemies, which I thought was awful at first, until I realised that all-in-all, it works very well. Depending on your weapon depends on how you attack. For example, melee weapons such as swords will be just one tile away for an attack to occur, but if a character say throws axes, you need to position them two tiles away instead so they can throw the axes towards an enemy. If they can target multiple enemies at once, they may split the damage if the AI deems it necessary to, or just attack one enemy for more damage. I like this simple formula that avoids the player themselves setting up positioning as well as attacks, and it's very easy once you get the hang of it. The combat isn't the most in-depth ever seen in a turn-based game, but in my opinion, it succeeds because of this. It creates a fast-paced action game where good positioning will win you the game, sort of like chess in a way. The other section is a pokemon styled run-around a map and find things game. You can seek out enemies that then take you into a more focused battle, and the best part is the quests, which allow for a lot of freedom to do what you want to do instead of sectioned levels. The story is crazy just like all of Behemoth's games, and I won't spoil it (even though there is only a certain amount of these story quests available currently) but there's a giant teddy bear that has crashed into the Earth. The narrator as always is ridiculous and funny. Customisation is plentiful and once again, outrageous. The hub town holds a market place for new fighters and weapons, an arena named the pit sort of like a colosseum as well as a home for you to mess with your characters and team. Overall, awesome game and a real treat to play. Simple, elegant, funny and over-the-top turn-based action with what seems to be a mind-boggling but intriguing story that never lets up on quick remarks, twists and plot. Support this game and Behemoth! They deserve it :D

Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								As a foreword this review was posted on the 6/2/17 and is with regards to the early access version of the game.Pit people is a delightful little strategy game by The Behemoth with narration by Will Stamper. In other words if you enjoyed the zany comedy of Battleblock Theatre, Castle Crashers or Alien Hominid then you will probably enjoy the style of humour found here. Whether it is the main 'story', multipart quests or the shorter sidequests the dialogue is constistently funny without getting too repetitive.The gameplay is a simplistic turn based combat system that takes place over a hexagonal grid. You assemble a team via collecting new units by defeating enemy armies and then customising them with various collectible items, mostly cosmetics but with some offering varied stats or attack styles. While the player's control over their units is limited (you pick where they move but not who they attack) your ability to customise the contents of your team adds a lot of depth to what you can do. Fans of games such as X-Com or Fire Emblem will likely enjoy what the game has to offer but it is also accessible enough for players new to the genre.Multiplayer operates smoothly with no real connection problems and offers both local and online co-op and versus. While some units may currently be considered suboptimal and others might be considered above average there is no feeling of there being a single perfect team composition in multiplayer, versus matches often featuring relatively varied teams.At present the main concern to be had with the game is that it is incomplete. Considering the low price I'd say even in it's unfinished state you will likely get your monies worth, especially as it seems bug free (in my experience at least) but if you are only planning to play the single player content you might want to wait for the full release. At present the storyline  consists of the tutorial content and a single mission, with numerous subquests and 4 quest chains also available. Hopefully the full release will expand upon this considerably, ideally with additional unit types being added as well.

Posted: March 8
Early Access Review
								Imagine playing a game of chess where you could make up the rules for your pieces.What makes the game interesting though, is that your enemy makes up their rules as well...Now imagine having an oddly deep bond with each and every one of your pieces that aren't so much pieces on a board anymore... but actual characters. Chosen, equipped, clothed, and trained by you since the day you found them wandering in the wilderness with their original pack of heathens. Finally, imagine watching all of your beautiful pieces you love and treasure so dearly getting murdered one of one thousand ways, one at a time, right before your very eyes.Now realize you cannot even begin to comrprehend what i'm talking about, unless you have played this game.One of a kind gem, just like the other games that the Behemoth backs, and I will probably play this game casually for the rest of my life.Great gameplay, a great experience, original content, and it's updated with new items and quests almost every month?Worth every single penny.

Early Access Review
								The various job clases of Fire Emblem meet XCOM's crazy RNG and then for the cherry on top, add a whole bunch of crude humor, references, and memes with the art style and explosions The Behemoth loves to show off. Throw in RNG for which character will get attacked by a unit, what hex tiles Area of Effect will splash into, if a unit blocks a projectile, and/or a unit dodging melee attacks and you have a wacky, chaotic, and hilarious game. Co-op is a lovely touch that will have you raging or laughing with a buddy over kill stealing or friendly fire incidents that just comes down to RNG.Rainbow Horses having the runs and skid marking the battlefield as they scoot across tiles is such a subtle and brilliant touch.12 Kobold rushers in PvP are goofy. As are teams of Zombies and Rainbow Horses. PvP will be getting balance patches and the unit combinations and customizations will slowly form a "build of the week" until a meta is formed.

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								Pit people is a game made by Behemoth, and that's why it's good!That's it, go home.You're still here?Aaagh, fine.I'll keep things simple by explaining all things this game could be compared to.Because I'm lazy.Adventure Time: definitely. The game is set in a colorful, cartoonish fantasy world that has some elements of the modern world (and also takes place after the apocalypse). The main character is just a normal guy who suddenly becomes a hero and meets all kinds of crazy characters, fights monsters and hangs out with 3 friends: a princess, a sexy Spanish lady and his cyclops bro. The game also mixes random humor and serious moments like the show.XCOM: Eeeeeeh. Apparently every turn based RPG game is going to be compared to XCOM 2012 these days. I'm just going to say that this is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. There's no permadeath or saving the world from the alien invasion (not yet at least) but you can create your 6 member team from randomly generated characters, but honestly I would rather compare this game to Final Fantasy Tactics series and other games from the Turn Based Strategy RPG gentre.Pokemon: now that may sound weird, but let me explain. You can recruit all sorts of characters and creatures with different abilities to your team, but it works in a different way than you would expect. When you're fighting someone and see a character you want in your team, you need to leave that unit alone and kill everyone else, then you can make someone drop a cage on this unit and BAM: now it's yours. There's a ton of different units you can find, and also all of them have strenghts and weaknesses against others.Other Behemoth games: IMO it might be the best game they ever made. The gameplay is super cool, the humor is fantastic and the artstyle is really good as well.Now you might think two different things depending of what kind of person you are.1. "Ham Man, I don't play turn based RPG's that much/I never played a turn based RPG in my life, will I enjoy this?"It's not as complicated as for example Final Fantasy Tactics on PS1, the rules are pretty simple and you should learn how to play quickly.2."Ham Man, I played turn based RPG's all my life, will this game challenge my genius mind and allow me to destroy powerful enemies with flawless tactics?"I know that I said that the game is simple literally 30 seconds ago, but don't be alarmed. The game can offer a fair amount of challenge as well. There's Insane Mode that greatly increases the difficulty, Unfair Challenge that makes you fight 3 battles in one go (yes, there is Insane Unfair Challenge), you can also fight other players. There's a ton of different ways you can build your team and some characters have good synergy with others. Tactical planning and using the abilities of your heroes well is important in PVP and harder challenges.Well, I think that's it.The game is cool, buy it.Bye.

Early Access Review
								Apart from a slightly annoying bug, which makes you unable to scroll down in order to select characters while in combat, and the occasional framedrop or two, Pit People was one of the more stable experiences to have with Early Access games. More than that, it’s one of the most polished Early Access titles one can get their hands on. It was genuinely fun and hilarious, always making it clear that the team had a unified vision to which they’ve stuck quite well. It goes without saying that I’m looking forward to see what the next updates will bring and, more importantly, to getting my hands on the full version of the game. In the meantime, though, I’ve a ghost wearing an afro to catch. Full Review[www.noobfeed.com].

Posted: January 25
Early Access Review
								Behemoth never disappoints. A new refreshing game with great art and fun gameplay, Pit People is just like Behemoth's other classic games with the humor, voice acting, and ridiculous weapons and cosemetics to match. :) I usually don't get into strategy and turn based games, but Pit People makes those who aren't interested in that genre love it. Such a weird combination of genres comes together in Pit People, and it's great. There is so much to do in Pit People, and I can't wait to see what Behemoth has in store for the full release of this game. Since it is still in development, some things are not complete(like the story), but there is much to explore. They are very attentive to the community as many major improvements from Beta recommended from the community and I love that. Tutorial is much better now and so are the animations since beta. Current early access price of $15 is a good deal, considering how well developed and different this game is from other mainstream games. (After early access the price will go up to $20). Some cons to the game are the controls for mouse+keyboard. The game was designed for Xbox, and is best played on a controller. It's still ok though, but if you don't have a controller, you may find it annoying. There is also no world map, and the screen makes it hard to see sometimes while traveling. It is different and a cool idea, but can be frustrating.P.S there is a LOT of grinding(it is part RPG). If that's not your thing, then don't get this game.Thank you for another wonderful game, Behemoth <3

Early Access Review
								Got the game on day one of its early access steam release for a friend and I. This is some of the most fun I've had in a long while from a -$20.00 game which is fun with a friend but also maintains its enjoyability in single player. If you enjoyed the humor of previous behemoth games you'll definitley love this with some fantastic voice acting from Will stamper (Hatty from battle block theater). This is a game thats clearly gone through careful development and is the most prepared Early access game I've ever played with the only thing ive been dissapointed with is the length of the story which is quite short at the moment (Devs have already said this isnt the complete story and there will be more!) this game easily gets an 8/10 for me and I hope to be there for the continued development of this game!

content:
Posted: January 17
Early Access Review
								I feel compelled to make a review for this phenominal title by none other than the Behemoth. I've loved their games ever since Alien Homonid. Pit People takes a new perspective on the strategic turn-by-turn action of Fire Emblem. The Behemoth shine with their comedic charm once again. The humor is perfect. The thought of a goliath sized space bear with star nipples plumiting into a planet turning everything into turn-by-turn world dictated by another evil space bear with star nipples is something only the Behemoth can think of. Now I saved the final part of my little spiel for one of the best gaming soundtracks EVER. Period. The animation is crisp, combat is spectacular, diverse species to build a team with, incredible soundtrack, hilarity every step of the way. 11/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								First of all, i have never heard of the behemoth. But, i have played games at newgrounds a long time ago and it was fun. I was looking at some indie rogue like games and suddenly i saw castle crashers a few weeks ago. Then, i saw that pit people will be releasing on 13th January. After watching a few gameplay videos, I bought the game on that day and knowing that it is release as early access. i have played turn based strategy like ff tactics and tactics ogre. This game definately attract my interest. For me, i really like the humor that resembles rick and morty. The animation that resembles adventure time and catchy soundtrack. The gameplay is quite simple and the difficulty level is okay. They also provide insane difficulty level. Loots are basically reskin of equipable item and only few provide different attributes such as elemental resistance or damage. It is understandable due to there are too many items. Maybe different stats for items will be implement by dev or not. I am okay with that.The game is still at early access stage. Some people are complainig about the short main story. But it is not a problem for me. Within 11 hours of playing this game, i did not touch the main story. I only played side quest, explore the map, catching units and played pvp. PVP is quite interesting because of the leaderboard motivates me to get a better position on it. It is understandable that finding people on online match is quite hard for sea server. But it is easy to find people in online coop for me.This is my opinion. I recommend this to people who like this kind of game. You could watch youtube for gameplay. If you only want to play single player, it is advised to wait for the full game to be released.

Early Access Review
								For an early access game there's a surprising amount of content. Whether it's making a new team comp or finding some new quests out in the wild, or doing PvP in the pit, there is an endless stream of content to play through in this current state of the game. The humor is on point just as all Behemoth games are and the concept of the game is simple and well executed. I normally don't like recommending early access games but this is an exception.

content:
Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								Even in this game's current Early Access status, I can easily recommend this to my friends, and to anyone who's played either Battleblock Theater or Castle Crashers. This game has all the charm and uniqueness as these past games, taking aspects of them both (i.e. The Narrator from Battleblock Theater, the stupid but well implimented poop jokes from Castle Crashers) and smashing them all together into a 4X turn based strategy RPG game that re-defines the genre entirely, continuing the saga Behemoth has left behind in their unique twists on the genres of games.I don't know how to make a long enough or good enough review to give this game the justice it deserves. It's fantastic, and it could easily be released right now but the fact that the devs want people to bug test it, while also adding new things to the game while it's in early access is amazing.Behemoth and Blizzard are definitely my favorite developers (Blizzard because they don't do DLC's for Overwatch, and Behemoth for their creative games and wonderful humor.)Thanks a lot guys, and keep up the good work!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								At first the game seems of, the combat is wierd, the world seems limited (but the comedy is on point). But once you settle into it becomes really fun. The combat becomes strategic (especially if you play on insane mode), its not that strategic that you need to take ages to cotemplate strategies each turn, it just forces you to be smart with every move (perfect for PvP). The world expands into a difficult and large open world, jam packed with content (very strange content). After getting through a weak start the game becomes amazing.My only dissapointment are the choices of weapons and armour, I was expecting a more RPG type weapon system how every individual item has their own stats, but the game only has set 5 weapons with different stats for each type of weapon (e.g. sheild, sword, ranged). However, this is redeemed by the wide array of characters that you can have in your party. This can vary your strategies depending on the set of character you captured. I'm honetly suprised how this game isn't on the "top seller" or "popular new releases" section on steam. It might be early access but I havent come across any bugs.I think this game is a 9/10, would be 10/10 if the beggining was more engaging.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
Early Access Review
								Pure excellence as is the usual with The Behemoth. The animation is wonderful, the art style awesome, the humor hilarious and off the wall, the gameplay is super solid, the story is so far, priceless. I love the narrator. The game does kind of fail to explain its self very well, luckily I'm familiar with turn based, grid based, rpg games. The fact that it IS LOCAL CO-OP, makes it awesome for me and the wife.  To be to the point, thus far it's a 8/10 easy. It could very well be as good as castle crashers in a lot of ways. We could have an award winner here.PROS-Great Behemoth style game just like Castle Crasher and Battle Block Theater.-Wonderful humor/art style-Solid turn based RPG gameplay, great animations-Local Co-Op (as well as online, so far though it seems to be invite co-op only)-Online Competitive play, if you're into that sorta... thing...-Absolutely mind blowing soundtrackCONS-The tutorial is rather haphazard. While I slid right into playing, I didn't feel like how the game worked was very well explained, it just felt familiar enough to pick up and play.-The quest system didn't seem to be explained at all, I didn't even realize I had "quests" outside of what the story narrative covered as the general 'story' quest. I didn't realize there were quests in a sort of quest log format that could be turned in for rewards until I saw my first quest complete pop up. - Your "Home base" i.e the town you return to during your adventures to rest and upgrade party members, gets randomly moved about every 3 returns to it or so. It is only ever moved when you are in it, so you don't have to worry about it moving while you're gone, but you can't really make any exploration progress this way because you're continously being moved to new places you don't know.-You have a limit to the amount of loot you can carry, you must return to town to deposit your booty and then head back out. -Trading is not explained in co-op, at least not in local. When you return home in co-op you'll get a screen of loot between you and your partner, the left and right represent players 1 and 2 respectively. From the start nothing is 'selected', anything selected is automatically given to the other player. I say given, instead of trade, because if the other player doesn't select anything, they still get everything you clicked anyway for free. This isn't a problem, especially in co-op where maybe someone got something they don't need but the other does. The point is, what this screen even meant let alone how it worked, was not explained at all. -So far no luck match making. I'm not saying it doesn't work, I just am saying I've tried to find someone to do the Pit Co-Op with and gotten nothing three times over two days.

content:
Posted: January 30
Early Access Review
								It's like a cross between earthbound and south park canada without the vulgarity. One of the few games I've laughed my♥♥♥♥♥off while losing. There is almost no story at this point, but the multiplayer, sidequests, and random map stuff will still keep you busy, for the price I'd say its worth it in its current state.On the down side, mouse and keyboard controls are not intuitive, the game is definately prioritizing consoles with its design, it's not terrible but it does need mentioned.Edit: The devs have assured the community that the controls were an attempt to streamline gameplay, and the game is fast paced which is difficult to accomplish with a turn based game. They have also said that making them less clunky is something they are working on.

content:
Posted: February 8
Early Access Review
								Excellent game by Excellent DevsGame may be in early access, but Devs are active in their communities, and keep everyone up to date with the latest plans and info. Another oddity of Early access is the game runs with practically Zero issues, I myself have never had any. The game is very polished and depending on how complete you want to be, there are many many hours of gameplay. It took me over 30 hour to do all the side quest currently in game, and at over 150 hours I’m still collecting things.The only draw back of this early access is the main storyline is not finished. In place is a solid game, with tons of side quests, over 1000 collectables, many different units, PVE, and PVP Arena, and a ton more features on the way. Even if your hesitant of Early access, if this games gameplay is your type of game, I HIGHLY recommend grabbing it before release,

Again, I'm not an RTS buff, but the Behemoth is giving me a chance to enjoy the genre of game.

content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								When you hear the name "Pit People", I'm sure the first thing that comes to mind is a game about underground cannibals battling to get to the surface. This game is nothing like that. Yes, I'm pretty sure there's a cannibal or two somewhere. Aside from that, this game has solid, exciting gameplay that never seems to get too boring or repetitive. The humor is so quality that you could impress your dad. Playing co-op is a must. If you don't have a friend, it is worth kidnapping somebody just to experience the multiplayer. I do not think kidnapping is a good idea, but I also think missing out of the multiplayer is like missing out on some of the best fun this game has to offer. Yes, there's still some kinks to iron out, and some things aren't very well explained, leaving you to figure it out on your own. Overall, a very solid of a buy. I'd give it a "rock" rating of solidity.

content:
Posted: March 18
Early Access Review
								Ah, Pit People...Pit People is a great game, and with it being early access, has huge potential. I am a huge fan of The Behemoth, and, as with all Behemoth games it has great humor in it, the narrator (who is Stamper again, by the way) is pretty much god and will do whatever he wants, moving the main city randomly around the map whenever he wants, and  just messing with the characters. The story so far is about 2 hours, maybe 2 and a half (although, maybe a little shorter if they explained you needed cages to properly recruit people, god, that took me like, three whole fights to realise you needed a cage to "recruit" someone) you create your own team, which can consist of whoever you want, each character can have a different weapon, helmet and shield, all cracters have there own eqipment and a team can have up to six members. There are 6 base "classes" for a team, Assault, Ranger, Healer, Big Dude, Recruiter and Mid-Range personAssaulters are your main attack people, Rangers sit at the back and shoot, Healers do just that, heal damdged team members, Big Dudes do a lot of damdge, have a lot of health but con only move a few Hexes, Recruiters are not super powerful, but can get you new team members and Mid-Range People can throw, uh, stuff to stun enemies. The game lets you choose your team pretty much how you want it and, if you want you can go six rangers. Personally, i go for two Assaulters, a Healer, a Ranger and a Big Dude, which unfortunately means i only have five due to Big Dudes taking up 2 slots on your team,The gameplay is simple but nice, you tell your team members to go here, if they can they attack the enemy or heal your team they do, if not they just kinda, stand there. Then the enemy do the same thing. Ten you do it. Then the enemy.Then you, ect. The gameplay might not be super complex, but when you get a kill it feels super satysfying.A great game with good humor, satisfying gameplay and lovely strategy. It has great potential, and will probably become a 10/10 when fully released, though due to it not having tons to do currently, i would say about 8/10, but i still frigging love it.~Dusty

content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								I am really enjoying the game! So I watched gameplay videos etc to get a sense of wether Pit People would be for me. I took a leap (with my credit card that's no unheard of) and I do not regret my decision for one second! The game isn't perfect but it's great for me. I'll list pros and cons and depending on your taste in games you might have a different experience.Pros- Simple to learn system. You move your character to where you want and if they can do an action in that space they will. - Character customization: You have your stock plot characters but you can also recruit any of the denizens of the world. You can't change their name or "class" if they're a monster, but you can collect literally 1000 different helmets, (which are somtimes hair styles) weapons, armor etc. Getting a character with a funny name is many a player's goal.- No bugs for me. I haven't found any bugs yet, or graphical or sound problems.- I love the music, it wavers between this weird techno to silly haphazard metal.- The animation is smooth and I like the simple style.Cons-The game itself is not complete and that's ok for me, it tells you and you can keep playing after that part in the plot. Technically a con but it's out there in plain site for us to see befor we purchase.-Atmosphere. I enjoy the abstract and comedic design of the game's world, some people might not. This isn't a dark and brooding tactical rpg clearly. - Interface! I DID have trouble figuring out what buttons do what in some cases because they are simpily a graphic, not actually labeled. I don't like how if you hover to another character by accident or another equipment (like from helmets to weapons tab) you go to that field as if you clicked. BUT you can also go there by clicking so it creates some confusion but it's not game breaking or anything. I suggest one interface method or the other when it comes to menu screens. Everywhere else in the game is great.Watch videos, ask the message boards, check out screenshots, whatever you wanna do. As always see how you feel befor you buy this game and research. I made a good purchase.

content:
Posted: March 18
Early Access Review
								Ah, Pit People...Pit People is a great game, and with it being early access, has huge potential. I am a huge fan of The Behemoth, and, as with all Behemoth games it has great humor in it, the narrator (who is Stamper again, by the way) is pretty much god and will do whatever he wants, moving the main city randomly around the map whenever he wants, and  just messing with the characters. The story so far is about 2 hours, maybe 2 and a half (although, maybe a little shorter if they explained you needed cages to properly recruit people, god, that took me like, three whole fights to realise you needed a cage to "recruit" someone) you create your own team, which can consist of whoever you want, each character can have a different weapon, helmet and shield, all cracters have there own eqipment and a team can have up to six members. There are 6 base "classes" for a team, Assault, Ranger, Healer, Big Dude, Recruiter and Mid-Range personAssaulters are your main attack people, Rangers sit at the back and shoot, Healers do just that, heal damdged team members, Big Dudes do a lot of damdge, have a lot of health but con only move a few Hexes, Recruiters are not super powerful, but can get you new team members and Mid-Range People can throw, uh, stuff to stun enemies. The game lets you choose your team pretty much how you want it and, if you want you can go six rangers. Personally, i go for two Assaulters, a Healer, a Ranger and a Big Dude, which unfortunately means i only have five due to Big Dudes taking up 2 slots on your team,The gameplay is simple but nice, you tell your team members to go here, if they can they attack the enemy or heal your team they do, if not they just kinda, stand there. Then the enemy do the same thing. Ten you do it. Then the enemy.Then you, ect. The gameplay might not be super complex, but when you get a kill it feels super satysfying.A great game with good humor, satisfying gameplay and lovely strategy. It has great potential, and will probably become a 10/10 when fully released, though due to it not having tons to do currently, i would say about 8/10, but i still frigging love it.~Dusty

content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								So I have not been given anything free, and it's rare that I write reviews.This is a wonderful start to a very fun game! As it is early access, it is unfinished in the plot/storyline, but so much fun that it is worth the current price for a few laughs and a fresh spin on positioning based combat systems. Here are my Pros and Cons. Some of the Cons list will be the kind of things that are almost always an issue in early access, but a Pro is a Pro and a Con is a Con.Pros:1. Excellent animation in a captivating style. It turns brutal and nearly meaningless violence into a humorous romp with silly characters that throw strawberries and beer bottles as shuriken and use fences and beach umbrellas for shields. Despite the 2D style it has a visual depth and variety that keeps it interesting.2. Outrageous and hilarious narrator that is apparently quite evil and argues with the main character about how the story is supposed to go.3. The world changes constantly, with the heroes home moving from place to place in the world. Not clear if it's procedurally generated each time, but don't focus too much on scouting with this game at present. You'll always be somewhere new soon. It forces a different style of planning and play in that way.4. Currently playable in a way that the combat system can be learned and understood in it's current form. Fun fights.5. Unkillable allies. Allies get wasted left and right in some fights. If you lose somebody(0 health) they will be waiting when you return home. No cheesy paying gold for resurrection mechanics. You are penalized by not having them in the field for that time, but you can spring for a resurrection potion if you know you might lose someone before completing a quest. They are pricey.6. No leveled items as yet. Some items seem more common than others in each game area, but there is not a "sword of a thousand truths" to completely destroy the game balance. All weapons and items have a direct weight/damage/special ratio, so a big sword with high damage and a flame attack may be all a character can carry, while a guy with a light sword might carry the heaviest shield, or forgo armor for greatly improved movement speed.Cons: 1. Unpolished combat mechanics. The controller system could use a few improvements as some of the controls seem unintuitive especially around interacting with the home and markets. Have not played keyboard controls, but the controller(xbox) works well enough to play, I just make a lot of mistakes due to buttons functioning differently from menu to menu. Dumb mistakes in this combat system can be costly since combat is accomplished solely by moving to take advantage of the strengths and weaknesses of each character/enemy. It is hard to tell if the system of strengths/weaknesses/elements is rudimentary or just complex and not fully applied. The Devs seem to be aiming for a wide variety of playstyles with a complex and intuitive turn based combat system. I think they can do that, and will eventually. This whole game centeres around strategic combat encounters.2. Weapons and armor don't have much variety in function, despite many many different appearances. Some weapons have special properties, but most are standard in function with a different appearance. I prefer this to a game with progressive overpowering of items and player groups, but more variety of weapon/armor functions would be nice. Ex. A mace beats in a helm but does less damage than a sword of equal weight. Helms deflect swords for greatly reduced damage, and light armor or no armor may offer a slight dodge chance. That's about it for armor effects. Many more ways of making fights dynamic at the equipment level through unique abilities(rather than leveled items and such) is how I hope they improve this. Bows and other ranged weapons are not very useful yet, in that they create a more unrealiable team when it comes to combat, though they are not useless, just uninteresting.3. Grindy. Unfinished story, yes, but if you don't do story quests then all that is left is to fight and collect fighters at the moment. The characters level up over time, but why is currently unclear. It seems to make them stronger slowly, but so what? This is probably a mechanic not yet well developed. As the game is, I have no reason to care if the characters level up, and kind of hope that aspect of the game is removed for some alternative.Overall this is a whole lot of fun and laughs, and mentally stimulating to play. My 11 yr. old Nephew thinks it's funny, and I would consider it generally appropriate for modern kids. Needs a lot of work to add more than one dimension of play. I don't play "collect them all" games, so I hope Devs continue to focus on refining and expanding combat mechanics first and foremost. I hope this has been helpful.

content:
Posted: January 13
Early Access Review
								Behemoth, the people who brought us Alien Hominid, Castle Crashers, and Battleblock Theater. This is their latest game, and I already enjoy it. This game is a turn based strategy RPG, and it's a lot of fun. The mechanics are easy, the gameplay is fun and rewarding, and the art style and music is fantastic. There's also a lot of character customization, so you'll be able to make your fighters look really cool, or really goofy. Also, there's this recruit system that this game has that if you defeat all enemies but one, you can capture that last enemy. It's a good mechanic, and it allows the player more freedom and control on what they can have. There's actually a story to this game, but because it's in Early Access, only some of it is here. You'll finish what they have right now in rought 2 hours, maybe a little more or less depending on how fast you're playing. This game has a lot of grinding, and a lot of items, and it's also  open world, so you'll be able to explore and collect as much as you would want. Despite this game being in an Early Access state, I would still recommend anyone who has played Behemoth's games before, or people who like these kinds of games in general. I trust that this game will be in its fully released state soon because I trust Behemoth, and they've never failed to impress.

number of helpful: 15 of 32 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
Early Access Review
								I enjoyed the game, but for 15$ right now I would wait. This game kind of feels like a demo right now. The story is very short, and there are some side quests. I understand, its early access. The game does look very promising, and I think it can be a better game than it is already if there is more added. I did enjoy quite a bit of the things already though. Combat is simple (Which can be bad for some people, I personally feel like it maybe could use some more interaction,) if you enjoyed the previous games humor, you will enjoy this games humor, the sound track is great, the characters are ok, and there is co op campaign. This is all brought down by due to how short everything ends. (Granted it is only 2 players, if they would somehow manage 4 player, I would love this game.) (Last thing, I forgot to shut this down as I was leaving. Thats why I have 2 and a half more hours than I actually played.) If you have any response to this, dont just say this review isnt helpful and leave. Leave a comment on why you think Im wrong. (tl;dr) The game is good, but too short to be worth 15$ at the moment.Overall, I am hopeful. Mainly because this game was made by Behemoth. I know they make really good games and I am almost 100% sure this will be another good one. Just have to wait for awhile. I will change my review if it gets better later.

content:
Posted: January 17
Early Access Review
								I don't know much about Pit People, but I do know the plot for JoJo's Bizarre Adventure!In 1999 in the town of Morioh located in S-City, Josuke Higashikata is a popular boy in high school who becomes quick friends with one of his classmates, Koichi Hirose. When Josuke's nephew Jotaro Kujo (who's older than he is due to his father being his nephew's grandfather, hence the age difference) appears, Josuke is suddenly pulled into the world of the supernatural powers known as stands. One of DIO's henchmen has brought the Bow and Arrow to Morioh and someone has been using it on various people in the town creating Stand users—as discovered when one of them, the murderer Anjuro "Angelo" Katagiri, uses the power of his Stand Aqua Necklace to try and kill Josuke for interfering with his plans to rob a store and generally disturb the peace in Morioh earlier. Aqua Necklace manages to kill Josuke's grandfather, Ryohei Higashikata, in revenge for him being jailed by him. Josuke and Jotaro eventually capture him and, as a consequence of insulting Josuke's hair, ends up getting fused to the rock he was leaning on at the time, becoming a tourist attraction known as "Angelo Rock" in the process.

content:
Posted: March 31
Early Access Review
								Note: Please do not buy this game until it is fully released. (Or not, whatever. I liked it even though it had little content.)So Pit People is a RPG game about moving units to attack each other. Once a goal is achieved or all other units are dead, you win.The main story is very short, but there's nothing else to expect from early access. There are some fun sidequests and you can keep unlocking new characters, with 1000+ items to customize with.I'm very excited to see the full release of this game, good job Behemoth! :)

content:
Posted: March 16
Early Access Review
								Pros:1. Behemoth's art style.2. Behemoth's comedy style.3. Fun music, lore and loots.4. Casual gameplay and very easy to follow.5. Can Catch more people to join the crew like Pokemon.Cons:1. Gameplay a bit repetitive but since it's early access not much to do. They could improve more in the future I believe, like special superpower for each unique characters, more lore and make special loots.Pretty much that about it for now in my opinion can't judge the game too early it's early access but since it's Behemoth's game I know it's gonna be great because I have played Castle Crashers and Battleblock Theatre satisfied with both of them. I'm looking forward to see this game full version and see more features. Meanwhile, Here have some teeny tiny iced cream, I know you love them.

content:
Posted: January 28
Early Access Review
								So, far this is my favorite game of 2017. Behemoth has delivered with a fun comedic, and unique spin on strategy games. The story as of right now is short but, sweet. Combat is creative, and inuitive. Charcters are unique, and costemizable. I remember feeling the way I did when I got Civ V. The Behemoth has really pulled through on that One More Turn ordeal. Even though this is in early access this is a must buy for any Behemoth fan, and a must buy for any strategy fan. As if Posiedon himself put his hand out in friendship ,and they spat in his mouth!

content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								Okay so, let me say I don't hate this game. I've actually been looking forward to it since it was annouced, as I am a huge fan of everything Behemoth does along with one of my favorite actors/voice actors/people Stamper. However, this game really just isn't fun to me. Like, the combat itself is extremely weak and unsatisfying as nothing really feels like you're actually doing anything. You can't plan for any battle, you can't choose who you attack, weapons are often just reskins and stats don't really matter too much. I know no one really cares about my opinion, so I'll just be brief. I find it hilarious, like the portion that is done was really funny as Stamper always is. The humor is here as they are known to do, but gameplay wise it's the weakest game yet. I'm really hoping somehow they fix it since nothing really feels fun besides hearing Stamper make silly voices.

content:
Posted: March 23
Early Access Review
								Soundtrack is AWESOME, as is narrator writing BUT gameplay and long term progression too vague and too random As a tactical "rpg-lite" the gameplay is ok, based on your group composition you subjugate and loot new team members and items to give you more options for more team compositions. As early access the story line is unfinished but the writing and 4th window breaking is funny. However there is little progression, and even early on i see a grinding mechanism which is completely random and arbitrary. As you play the game your characters supposedly level up but they do not become visibly stronger as numbers are not defined , the levels on the individual characters seem completely random and no measure for tactical planning is allowed for the player, for example my level 4 characters caught a level 25 mob. Did it suddenly mean all the random encounters scaled up? Did it not matter? who knows as no info is given. Random encounters are completely random as well, You have no idea of the difficulty or composition of the random encounters. my low level team was near wiped out when i first met pixies doing AOE fire damage and i had no clue the pixie was there as i could not click on the encounter to get a clue . all in all at this point i cannot recommend this game as RPG or a adventure rpg or a tactical game unless you are completely into PVP. Which i did not indulge as the frustrating randomness of single player mode was too annoying

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								I wanted this game to be good, but there are a few very important things that makes it disappointing. You get a team, and it's a turn by turn game where you get your team to fight other teams. The only thing you can control during combat is the movement of your characters. This is important because you can't control who your characters attack. Everything is extremely tanky, therefore no strategic planning is involved. Also, there are over 1000 items but 99% of them are cosmetic. What this means is that there are basically no strategy involved in what items your characters should equip. Yes, there are some very minor strategic decisions but they won't yield any interesting gameplay.
